author: barnabemonnot
content: hi there, I havenâ€™t given too many updates in the last two weeks for personal reasons but am catching up on the latest messages here. Unfortunately I am not able to join the call tonight but prepared some notes here: https://github.com/ethereum/rig/blob/master/eip1559/notes-call3.md

author: timbeiko
content: Thanks! Just linked them in the agenda.

author: sky.cactus
content: What is the argument against clients setting `base_fee` very high so users can not worry about it?

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't believe there is any way for someone to profit or even reasonably troll a transaction.  The only reason to set an upper limit on `base_fee` would be if the user would rather the transaction *never* mine than mine for a price higher than X.

author: sky.cactus
content: e.g., if the user is willing to pay up to 0.1 ETH in fees, then why not just have the client set the base fee such that the transaction will at most cost 0.1 ETH?

author: sky.cactus
content: Then we only have to worry about the premium, which *should* be stable over time.  As long as your base_fee is high enough, the stable rate premium will get you mined.

author: sky.cactus
content: With perhaps an option for increasing the premium for those who *really* want next-block inclusion no matter what and are willing to pay for *guarantees*.

author: barnabemonnot
content: If you mean maxfee by base_fee, I donâ€™t disagree that the reasonable value for it is the willingness to pay of users. It would make the analysis much easier too, the mechanism would be fully truthful then. I am more concerned from a UX point of view what this looks like, I think it is a stretch to think users would input a large value and plan for paying even a thousandth of that. I do see defaults as an important part of that discussion though

author: barnabemonnot
content:
> With perhaps an option for increasing the premium for those who *really* want next-block inclusion no matter what and are willing to pay for *guarantees*.
<@301186049323958275>  

This is where the floating escalator helps. Out of the box it looks like EIP1559, with the extra bonus that if you want your increasing premium, you can configure it so

author: sky.cactus
content: Yeah, escalator for premium would help in times of extended congestion.

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't think it is unreasonable to write a client that just sets the base-fee to "something crazy large" and then tells the user the *estimated base fee*.

author: sky.cactus
content: The same client may just fix the premium to "going rate during uncongested times" premium.

author: sky.cactus
content: IMO, this would be a reasonable default as your transaction will almost certainly get mined eventually, where "eventually" is *likely* soon (unlike now, when "never" or "not for a very long time" are both common occurrences).  It also would be a plan that ensures you are not overpaying for gas.

author: sky.cactus
content: And it requires no user input for most cases.

author: sky.cactus
content: With escalator on top, we could do even better.

author: barnabemonnot
content: It still opens the possibility that this crazy large value is reached. I donâ€™t think there is a universal value that would fit every transaction, and so it collapses back to the case for me where users must know their WTP to set their maxfee, to prevent that one in a i donâ€™t know how many chance that they end up paying a lot due to having a high maxfee

author: sky.cactus
content: I agree the wallet/client will have to make an arbitrary choice as to what "crazy high" means.  10x current base fee is something like 7 minutes of continuously full blocks which I suspect will be pretty rare with 1559.

author: abdel.stark
content: <@!301186049323958275> <@!486501030046203915> You both mean feecap when you say basefee or maxfee ?

author: barnabemonnot
content: ha yes ðŸ™‚

author: abdel.stark
content: ok thanks

author: sky.cactus
content: Maybe?  I forget what the proper terms are.  ðŸ˜¬

author: abdel.stark
content: In the EIP : FEECAP serves as the absolute maximum that the transaction sender is willing to pay

author: sky.cactus
content: The thing set on a transaction that limits the highest base fee that can be charged.

author: abdel.stark
content: Yeah ok. This is feecap

author: sky.cactus
content: The number I'm referring to is exclusive of the premium.

author: abdel.stark
content: BTW This sentence should be removed: If GASPRICE < BASEFEE (due to the FEECAP), this means that the block.coinbase loses funds from this operation; in this case, we check that the post-balance is non-negative and throw an exception if it is negative.

author: abdel.stark
content: We decided to reject such transactions.

author: abdel.stark
content: Otherwise it would be possible to drain Eth from arbitrary accounts

content: Have blocks consistently been full during this ponzi clogging stuff on Eth?

author: kiwi.eth
content: Gas has been pretty high for like 3 weeks now

author: timbeiko
content: Analysis of the escalator that has just been published. I had an early view and it'd be great to get people's thoughts on the call ðŸ˜„ https://insights.deribit.com/market-research/analysis-of-eip-2593-escalator/

author: barnabemonnot
content: nice! should read it a bit more carefully but it also seems to advocate for 1559 first and then perhaps escalator on top too

author: abdel.stark
content: I would personally advocate for having them combined directly on the same hardfork

author: abdel.stark
content: With the floating escalator combination you propose <@!664249717949202460>  https://github.com/ethereum/rig/blob/master/eip1559/combination.md#floating-escalator-started-on-basefee

author: abdel.stark
content: And have EIP-2718 being a requirement of EIP-1559

author: abdel.stark
content: I don't think that extra-protocol implementations of escalator are a good thing

author: sendmoodz
content:
> Whether that reduces fees for individual users is impossible to say, since any UX gain can also induce demand for further transactions.
this is an odd point to make, all things equal it makes sense that fees would be reduced.

> Whenever blocks are not full, miners will include any transaction paying the minimum fee. This is the same in all proposals, and no first-price auction takes place. Since escalators donâ€™t matter unless there is a first-price auction, it also makes some of the authorsâ€™ considerations on the correct user-strategy moot.
i disagree with this, just because miners will include any transaction paying a minimum does not mean price discovery is efficient, and it may take wallets longer to discover the correct minimum than if they can specify a much lower minimum without risk of delaying a user's transaction beyond their preference
